entry.definition: a utility truck, pickup truck or ute in Australia

refers to a particular subculture of vagrants in Cape Town (from Afrikaans berg (mountain), originally referring to vagrants who sheltered in the forests of Table Mountain.) Increasingly used in other cities to mean a vagrant of any description.
Cinema (place)|cinema, movie theatre (now dated)
as in the UK this officially means a million million. Nowadays the American usage (one billion is one thousand million) is almost exclusively used.
cured meat, similar to jerky
same as American cookie, in South Africa, cookie is used for cupcake
spicy sausage from (Afrikaans) "farmer-sausage" (usually made mostly with beef)
hood of a car
national identity document (now dated)
a barbecue, to barbecue (from Afrikaans braaivleis)
a South African rand|Rand
eggplant (from Portuguese berinjela, also used in Indian English)
a wilderness region, remote from cities (from Shona language|Shona bundo, meaning grasslands)
as used in the UK, playing truant, skipping school/class
loaf of bread filled with curry, speciality of Durban, particularly Durban Indians
when pronounced {{IPA-en|k?f?i?}} refers to a convenience store not a coffee shop (originally such stores sold coffee and other basic items)
when someone says that they will "call" this typically means that they will make a telephonic call, not visit in person, phone and (less commonly) ring are also used
mobile phone
as in Britain this is used for cotton candy
besides meaning a scientist specializing in chemistry, the term is also used for a pharmacist and for a Pharmacy|drugstore (short for chemist shop in the latter case)
used for both French fries and Potato chip|potato crisps
traffic circle or roundabout
refers to typically light skinned South Africans of mixed European and Khoisan and/or Malay ancestry.
besides meaning attire worn to a dress-up party/play it also refers to a bathing suit (short for "swimming costume" or "bathing costume"), sometime abbreviated cozzie also used in Britain.
used exclusively for a cupcake
soft drink, fizzy drink not necessarily chilled
car glove compartment, also used in Britain
cannabis (drug)|marijuana, dag-gah, dagca (similar in pronunciation to an Arabic herb)
also used to mean a reservoir
a ditch of the type found in South African topography (from Zulu, 'wall')
plural erven - a plot of land for a building (from Cape Dutch).
as in Britain this is used for an apartment
typically refers to Association football|soccer

as in the United States and Australia refers to what is known as a motorway in Britain. The dominant forms are the National Roads, e.g the N1 from Johannesburg to Cape Town, and this term is also used as a referent.
a male gardener (of any age), typically Black people|Black (Commonly used by older white South Africans, now considered politically incorrect)
domestic water boiler
as formerly used in Britain, a Incandescent light bulb|light bulb
terms for Capsicum of various colours
under apartheid, typically referred to a self-governing "state" for black South Africans
a free-standing dwelling. Usage differs from the UK, where a house is not free-standing, unlike a bungalow.
hello, how are you, good morning (despite being a contraction (grammar) of 'how is it', howzit is almost exclusively a greeting, and seldom a question) [very colloquial]

an all purpose exclamative, can be used in any context where "really?", "uh-huh", etc. would be appropriate; for example: "I'm feeling pretty tired." "Is it?" (very colloquial). Often contraction (grammar)|contracted in speech to "izit"
conference (from Zulu, 'a matter for discussion')
a fruit preserve spread whether containing pieces of fruit or not, seldom called a "jelly" in South Africa. Similar to use in UK
when referring to food this always means what in American English is called 'jello', ie. a flavoured gelatine dessert never a fruit preserve spread
idiomatically used to mean soon, later, or in a short while, but not immediately.
a fibre-tip (coloured) art pen (from a local brand name)
a minivan, esp. Volkswagen (from the Volkswagen Type 2|Volkswagen 'Kombi' van)
as in Britain this terms is used for an elevator, but can also mean a passenger ride to a desired destination.

an apartheid-era urban area populated by Black people|Blacks, Cape Coloured|Coloureds or Indians (dated, replaced "Township (South Africa)|township" in common usage amongst White people|Whites, but still widely used by Black people|Blacks)
what is generally called a "high street" in Britain
school-leaving certificate or the final year of high school or a student in the final year, short for matriculation exemption. Equivalent internationally to A-Levels or Grade 12.
an ear of maize (from Afrikaans mielie)
used for both maize flour and the traditional porridge made from it similar to American grits, the latter also commonly known by the Afrikaans word pap
a sunshower.
traditional medicine, but also used to refer to all types of medicine, eg. cough muti is cough mixture.
orange-colored citrus fruit with separable segments and skin that is easily peeled (from Afrikaans), known as a Tangerine in Britain
idiomatically used to mean soon (sooner than just now in South Africa, but similar to just now in the United Kingdom)
as used in the UK, what is generally known as a diaper
a mechanical pencil, named after the first commercially inexpensive brand advertised on South African television in the 1980's.
a disposable plastic shopping bag.
currency, divided into 100 Cent (currency)|cents. The plural of rand is Rand, not Rands

besides the standard meaning, in South Africa this is also used for traffic lights. The etymology of the word derives from a description of early traffic lights as robot policemen, which then got truncated with time.
round free-standing building, usually with a thatched roof
as in Britain, a rubber eraser, but coloquially may also refere to a condom
Indian samosa
an exclamation denoting sympathy as in "shame, you poor thing, you must be cold"
illegal drinking establishment (also used in Scotland)
millipede (from Zulu and Xhosa, ukushonga, to roll up)
as a noun the same as American general store|store
a kebab on a stick
a cantaloupe (from Afrikaans)
an informal trading post/convenience store found in townships and remote areas
as a verb, this is only used for the present tense unlike in America where it is also used for the past tense. The form spat is used for the past tense.
besides other meanings referred to a school grade higher than grades 1 and 2 (now defunct)

entry.word: State President of South Africa|State President
entry.definition: head of state between 1961 and 1994 - now known as President
a 3.5 inch floppy disk, floppy is used exclusively for the old 5.25 inch or larger disks
besides other meanings referred to first two school grades sub A/B (now grades 1 and 2)
used for both a popsicle (frozen sucker) and a lollipop
confectionery, candy (singular sweet used for an item of confectionery)
sneakers, Athletic shoe|trainers (from Afrikaans tekkies)
shared taxi (usually a Share taxi|minibus taxi) as well as taxicab

agents provocateur having no official sanction from either the government or its opposition regardless of which one they consider themselves to be benefiting, used especially for alleged unknown provocateurs behind political unrest, their actions being described as third force activity
a grilled cheese sandwich, in contrast cheese on toast refers to unmelted cheese on toasted bread.
used for a modern battery operated flashlight as well as a traditional flaming torch
large residential suburb lacking city infrastructure, in particular the areas allocated to non-white South Africans under apartheid
virgin bush, especially grassland or wide open rural spaces
